vacs.description: Catalogs of photometrically-selected Emission Line Galaxies (ELGs) at z ≈ 0.8.
vacs.title: ELG Fisher selection catalog
vacs.abstract: Catalogs of photometrically-selected emission line galaxies (ELGs) at z ≈ 0.8. The catalogs are obtained using the griW and UgrizW Fisher selections defined in Raichoor et al. (2016), as described in Delubac et al. (2017). The griW catalog is based on SDSS g,r, and i band photometries as well as WISE W1 photometry. It covers both the South Galactic Cap (SGC) and the North Galactic Cap (NGC) of the SDSS footprint. The UgrizW catalog also include SDSS z band and SCUSS U band photometries. It is limited to the SGC.
vacs.authors: Timothée Delubac, Anand Raichoor, Johan Comparat, Stéphanie Jouvel, Jean-Paul Kneib, Christophe Yèche, Hu Zou, Joel R. Brownstein, Filipe B. Abdalla, Kyle S. Dawson, Adam D. Myers, Jeffrey A. Newman, William J. Percival, Francisco Prada, Ashley J. Ross, Donald P. Schneider, Xu Zhou, Z. Zhou, Guangtun Zhu

vacs.description: Variability information for eBOSS quasar targets
vacs.title: QSO variability
vacs.abstract: Variability information (Palanque-Delabrouille et al. 2016) for eBOSS quasar targets (Myers et al. 2015) using either Palomar Transient Factory (PTF) light curves or SDSS stripe 82 data.
vacs.authors: Eric Armengaud, Etienne Burtin, Nathalie Palanque-Delabrouille, Christophe Yèche, Peter Nugent, Russ Laher, Branimir Sesar

vacs.description: The eBOSS survey will obtain spectra of about 200,000 ELGs at redshifts z>0.6, providing a unique rich dataset of rest-frame NUV spectroscopy for astrophysical applications. For target selection purposes, the ELG pilot survey observed about 12,000 ELGs, among which about 8,600 are at 0.6<z<1.2. Zhu et al. (2015) presented the composite spectra of these galaxies, and in particular, investigated the blueshifted resonant absorption lines (Fe II, Mg II) and non-resonant emission lines (Fe II*) in the NUV, the signatures of ubiquitous galactic-scale outflows associated with star formation activities. Because the composite spectra are of great interest to the community, here we make them publicly available as a value-added product.
vacs.title: Composite Spectra of Emission-line Galaxies from eBOSS
vacs.abstract: The eBOSS survey will obtain spectra of about 200,000 ELGs at redshifts z>0.6, providing a unique rich dataset of rest-frame NUV spectroscopy for astrophysical applications. For target selection purposes, the ELG pilot survey observed about 12,000 ELGs, among which about 8,600 are at 0.6<z<1.2. Zhu et al. (2015) presented the composite spectra of these galaxies, and in particular, investigated the blueshifted resonant absorption lines (Fe II, Mg II) and non-resonant emission lines (Fe II*) in the NUV, the signatures of ubiquitous galactic-scale outflows associated with star formation activities. Because the composite spectra are of great interest to the community, here we make them publicly available as a value-added product.

vacs.description: AGN and galaxy cluster candidates target catalogue for SPIDERS
vacs.title: SPIDERS target selection catalogues
vacs.abstract: The SPIDERS Tier-0 target catalogs (Clerc et al. 2016; Dwelly et al. 2017), i.e. AGN and galaxy clusters candidates, were obtained by matching X-ray information from the ROSAT All-Sky Survey (RASS) and from XMM-Newton to multi-band photometric data. The SPIDERS AGN target catalogs contain 9,028 candidate targets from RASS and 819 from XMM. They enclose information on the X-ray sources, including flux measurements, and a quantitative measure of the reliability of the association to optical and AllWISE (Cutrie et al. 2013)data. The counterparts to X-ray extended sources (galaxy clusters) were identified using a red-sequence finding algorithm adapted from RedMapper (Rykoff et al. 2014). The target list contains galaxies likely to belong to a galaxy cluster, as indicated by their color, distance to the center and luminosity. The SPIDERS Galaxy Cluster target list contains 94,883 and 3,839 objects for RASS and XMM respectively. We additionally provide targeting catalogs for the SEQUELS area, similarly constructed although differing in their association and selection methods.
vacs.authors: SPIDERS team, T. Dwelly, M. Salvato, A. Merloni, A. Finoguenov, D. Coffey, N. Clerc et al.

vacs.description: We provide the catalogue of X-ray detected galaxy clusters spectroscopically confirmed using SEQUELS-DR12 SPIDERS spectroscopic data. Galaxy clusters were identified through the emission of their hot baryonic component as X-ray extended sources in RASS. The optical counterparts were found by optimally searching photometric data for the existence of a red-sequence formed by their member galaxies. Spectroscopic redshifts obtained by SPIDERS (in the SEQUELS programme) provide definitive confirmation of the clustered nature of these objects and their redshift (up to z~0.6). We assigned cluster membership combining an algorithm and visual validation of individual objects. The gas properties derived from X-ray observations (luminosity, temperature, R_{200}) are derived using precise cluster redshifts (\Delta_{z} ~ 0.001). We compute galaxy cluster velocity dispersions using several methods adapted to the low number of spectroscopic members per system (of the order 15-40) and we show that their values correlate with cluster X-ray luminosities, within expectations.
vacs.title: The SPIDERS-Clusters demonstration sample catalogue
vacs.abstract: We provide the catalogue of X-ray detected galaxy clusters spectroscopically confirmed using SEQUELS-DR12 SPIDERS spectroscopic data. Galaxy clusters were identified through the emission of their hot baryonic component as X-ray extended sources in RASS. The optical counterparts were found by optimally searching photometric data for the existence of a red-sequence formed by their member galaxies. Spectroscopic redshifts obtained by SPIDERS (in the SEQUELS programme) provide definitive confirmation of the clustered nature of these objects and their redshift (up to z~0.6). We assigned cluster membership combining an algorithm and visual validation of individual objects. The gas properties derived from X-ray observations (luminosity, temperature, R_{200}) are derived using precise cluster redshifts (\Delta_{z} ~ 0.001). We compute galaxy cluster velocity dispersions using several methods adapted to the low number of spectroscopic members per system (of the order 15-40) and we show that their values correlate with cluster X-ray luminosities, within expectations.

vacs.description: APOGEE's target selection algorithm includes many red-clump (RC) stars in the APOGEE sample. A new method for identifying red-clump stars from spectrophotometric data and its application to the APOGEE data was presented in Bovy et al. (2014). This technique creates a very pure sample of red-clump stars with minimal contamination from red-giant-branch, secondary-red-clump, and asymptotic-giant-branch stars. The narrowness of the RC locus in color-metallicity-luminosity space allows distances to the stars to be assigned with an accuracy of 5%-10%. The purity is estimated to be about 95%.
vacs.title: APOGEE Red-Clump (RC) Catalog
vacs.abstract: APOGEE's target selection algorithm includes many red-clump (RC) stars in the APOGEE sample. A new method for identifying red-clump stars from spectrophotometric data and its application to the APOGEE data was presented in Bovy et al. (2014). This technique creates a very pure sample of red-clump stars with minimal contamination from red-giant-branch, secondary-red-clump, and asymptotic-giant-branch stars. The narrowness of the RC locus in color-metallicity-luminosity space allows distances to the stars to be assigned with an accuracy of 5%-10%. The purity is estimated to be about 95%.

vacs.description: The first data release of the Gaia mission contains improved parallaxes and proper motions for more than 2 million stars contained in the Tycho-2 catalogue, among them 46,033 objects contained in the APOGEE DR14 allStar catalogue. We provide the cross-matched catalogue, as well as precise astro-spectro-photometric distances, extinctions, and orbital parameters for more than 30,000 stars in the APOGEE-TGAS dataset.
vacs.title: DR14 APOGEE-TGAS Catalogue
vacs.abstract: The first data release of the Gaia mission contains improved parallaxes and proper motions for more than 2 million stars contained in the Tycho-2 catalogue, among them 46,033 objects contained in the APOGEE DR14 allStar catalogue. We provide the cross-matched catalogue, as well as precise astro-spectro-photometric distances, extinctions, and orbital parameters for more than 30,000 stars in the APOGEE-TGAS dataset.
vacs.authors: F. Anders, A. B. Queiroz, B. Santiago, C. Chiappini, J. G. Fernandez-Trincado, A. Meza, M. Shetrone, J. Holtzman, the APOGEE-Gaia Working Group

vacs.description: DR-14 based distance estimations have been provided by four separate groups, which rely upon the calibrated stellar atmospheric parameters as given by DR14.  For each of the distance catalog contributors, the associated label, distance determination descriptor, and relevant  reference(s) are given as follows: BPG (Bayesian Technique; Santiago et al. 2016, Queiroz et al. 2017); NAOC (Bayesian Technique; Wang et al. 2016); NICE (Isochrone Matching Technique; Schultheis et al. 2014); and, NMSU (Bayesian Technique; Holtzman et al., in prep).  At a minimum, all groups have provided a preferred distance value as well as an associated error.  Some groups have given additional values/information as described in the datamodel and HDU1 of the fits file.
vacs.title: APOGEE DR14-Based Distance Estimations
vacs.abstract: DR-14 based distance estimations have been provided by four separate groups, which rely upon the calibrated stellar atmospheric parameters as given by DR14.  For each of the distance catalog contributors, the associated label, distance determination descriptor, and relevant  reference(s) are given as follows: BPG (Bayesian Technique; Santiago et al. 2016, Queiroz et al. 2017); NAOC (Bayesian Technique; Wang et al. 2016); NICE (Isochrone Matching Technique; Schultheis et al. 2014); and, NMSU (Bayesian Technique; Holtzman et al., in prep).  At a minimum, all groups have provided a preferred distance value as well as an associated error.  Some groups have given additional values/information as described in the datamodel and HDU1 of the fits file.
vacs.authors: Kaike Pan, Friedrich Anders, Mathias Schultheis, Jianling Wang, Anna Barbara Queiroz, Basilio Santiago, Jon Holtzman, Jennifer Sobeck, Jianrong Shi, Cristina Chiappini

vacs.description: After mitigating selection effects and Malmquist bias over the redshift range 2.1 ≤ z ≤ 3.5, we present high signal-to-noise composite spectra binned by luminosity, spectral index, and redshift. Discussed in Jensen et al. (2016), these composite spectra indicate spectral evolution while holding luminosity and spectral index constant. Also included are the differential spectra composites of each parameter, including one derived from CIV FWHM binning, revealing a redshift evolution spectral signature similar to both the luminosity and CIV FWHM signatures. These composite spectra give way to interpret quasar diversity, and can be used to improve the templates used in redshift classification.
vacs.title: Composite Spectra of Quasars Binned on Spectroscopic Parameters from DR12Q
vacs.abstract: After mitigating selection effects and Malmquist bias over the redshift range 2.1 ≤ z ≤ 3.5, we present high signal-to-noise composite spectra binned by luminosity, spectral index, and redshift. Discussed in Jensen et al. (2016), these composite spectra indicate spectral evolution while holding luminosity and spectral index constant. Also included are the differential spectra composites of each parameter, including one derived from CIV FWHM binning, revealing a redshift evolution spectral signature similar to both the luminosity and CIV FWHM signatures. These composite spectra give way to interpret quasar diversity, and can be used to improve the templates used in redshift classification.
vacs.authors: Trey W. Jensen, Vivek Mariappan, Kyle S. Dawson, Scott Anderson, Julian Bautista, Dmitry Bizyaev, William N. Brandt, Joel R. Brownstein, Paul Green, David W. Harris, Vikrant Kamble, Ian D. McGreer, Andrea Merloni, Adam Myers, Daniel Oravetz, Kaike Pan, Isabelle Pâris, Donald P. Schneider, Audrey Simmons, Nao Suzuki

vacs.description:
Up to now, SDSS has spectroscopically confirmed over half a million quasars with redshifts comprised between 0.1 and 6.5. Data Release 14 will contain about 150 000 new quasars with 0.9<z<3.5. In addition, about 70000 quasars have multi-epoch spectroscopy available.

The SDSS-DR14 quasar catalog (DR14Q) will contain all quasars observed as part of SDSS-I/II/III/IV, based on a refined automated procedure to identify quasars and a partial visual inspection of spectra of the remaining objects.
Spectroscopic measurements, such as refined redshift, automated BAL detection or emission-line fits, and multi-wavelength photometric information will be included in DR14Q.
vacs.title: The Sloan Digital Sky Survey Quasar Catalog: Fourteenth Data Release
vacs.abstract:
Up to now, SDSS has spectroscopically confirmed over half a million quasars with redshifts comprised between 0.1 and 6.5. Data Release 14 will contain about 150 000 new quasars with 0.9<z<3.5. In addition, about 70000 quasars have multi-epoch spectroscopy available.

The SDSS-DR14 quasar catalog (DR14Q) will contain all quasars observed as part of SDSS-I/II/III/IV, based on a refined automated procedure to identify quasars and a partial visual inspection of spectra of the remaining objects.
Spectroscopic measurements, such as refined redshift, automated BAL detection or emission-line fits, and multi-wavelength photometric information will be included in DR14Q.
vacs.authors: Isabelle Pâris, Patrick Petitjean, Eric Aubourg, Scott Anderson, Niel Brandt, Peter Doohyun Choi, Adam Myers, Graziano Rossi, Don Schneider, Gongbo Zhao, Alina Streblyanska, Patrick Hall, Axel de la Macorra, Jean-Paul Kneib

vacs.description:
We publish the south galactic cap Emission Line Galaxy (ELG) catalog used for the extended Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (eBOSS) of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey IV (SDSS-IV). Targets were selected using photometric data from the Dark Energy Camera Legacy Survey (DECaLS). We selected roughly 240 ELG targets per square degree. The great majority of these ELG lie in the redshift range 0.67 < z < 1.1 (median redshift 0.85). 

The SAS folder containing the VAC is not to be published.
vacs.title: The SDSS-IV Extended Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey: Emission Line Galaxy Target Catalog
vacs.abstract:
We publish the south galactic cap Emission Line Galaxy (ELG) catalog used for the extended Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (eBOSS) of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey IV (SDSS-IV). Targets were selected using photometric data from the Dark Energy Camera Legacy Survey (DECaLS). We selected roughly 240 ELG targets per square degree. The great majority of these ELG lie in the redshift range 0.67 < z < 1.1 (median redshift 0.85). 

The SAS folder containing the VAC is not to be published.
vacs.authors: J. Comparat, A. Raichoor, T. Delubac, JP. Kneib, C. Yeche, the eBOSS and DECaLS collaborations.

vacs.description: Catalogue of DR14 LRG redshifts from models using single, theoretically-motivated templates and restricted to exclude non-physical solutions.  These models are gridded on physical parameters; thus, the catalogue includes estimates for those physical parameters in addition to a higher success rate than the default eBOSS pipeline.  The redmonster software is detailed in full in Hutchinson et al. (2016).
vacs.title: Redshift Measurement and Spectral Classification Catalog with Redmonster
vacs.abstract: Catalogue of DR14 LRG redshifts from models using single, theoretically-motivated templates and restricted to exclude non-physical solutions.  These models are gridded on physical parameters; thus, the catalogue includes estimates for those physical parameters in addition to a higher success rate than the default eBOSS pipeline.  The redmonster software is detailed in full in Hutchinson et al. (2016).
vacs.authors: Timothy A. Hutchinson, Adam S. Bolton, Kyle S. Dawson, Joel R. Brownstein, Julian E. Bautista

vacs.description: Pipe3D is an IFU focused analysis pipeline that provide with intermediate dataproducts extracted from the datacubes in an automatic way focused on both the stellar population and the ionized gas properties. The details of the pipeline were presented in Sanchez et al. 2016a,b (RMxAA, 52, 21 & 171), showing some examples based on CALIFA and P-MaNGA datasets. The MaNGA dataproducts provided by Pipe3D will be included in a refereed article. They comprise a table including the integrated (cumulative properties), characteristic (values at the effective radius), and gradient of different quantities, included stellar mass, star-formation (and their densisities), oxygen and nitrogen abundances, dust attenuation, estimated gas density, stellar and gas velocity dispersions... Further more the dataset includes four datacubes that comprises the spatial resolved properties required to recover the star-formation histories, the average properties of the stellar populations, the emission line properties for 56 strong and weak emission lines (including the former ones together with the EW of the lines), and the most frequently used stellar indices, as described in the previous articles. For each galaxy we provide these four datacubes packed together as extensions in a single FITs file. In addition, the original header of the corresponding MaNGA datacube has been included as the 1st extension to keep track of the original dataset and in particular of the WCS (that it is shared between the different extensions).
vacs.title: MaNGA Pipe3D value added catalog: Spatially resolved and integrated properties of galaxies
vacs.abstract: Pipe3D is an IFU focused analysis pipeline that provide with intermediate dataproducts extracted from the datacubes in an automatic way focused on both the stellar population and the ionized gas properties. The details of the pipeline were presented in Sanchez et al. 2016a,b (RMxAA, 52, 21 & 171), showing some examples based on CALIFA and P-MaNGA datasets. The MaNGA dataproducts provided by Pipe3D will be included in a refereed article. They comprise a table including the integrated (cumulative properties), characteristic (values at the effective radius), and gradient of different quantities, included stellar mass, star-formation (and their densisities), oxygen and nitrogen abundances, dust attenuation, estimated gas density, stellar and gas velocity dispersions... Further more the dataset includes four datacubes that comprises the spatial resolved properties required to recover the star-formation histories, the average properties of the stellar populations, the emission line properties for 56 strong and weak emission lines (including the former ones together with the EW of the lines), and the most frequently used stellar indices, as described in the previous articles. For each galaxy we provide these four datacubes packed together as extensions in a single FITs file. In addition, the original header of the corresponding MaNGA datacube has been included as the 1st extension to keep track of the original dataset and in particular of the WCS (that it is shared between the different extensions).
vacs.authors: S.F.Sanchez,H.Ibarra-Medel, J. Barrera-Ballesteros, M. Cano-Diaz, L.Sanchez-Menguiano, V. Avila-Reese, and IA-UNAM-MaNGA Team

vacs.description: The MaNGA Firefly Stellar Populations VAC is based on the MaNGA DAP output and extends through stellar population model fitting. It complements the DAP by providing higher-order and model-based data products. The data products are centred on the full spectral fitting analysis carried out at the Portsmouth supercomputer. The data included in the VAC is used in several scientific analyses (SDSS-IV projects 100, 309 and others in future). More information can be found in the MaNGA product proposal posted on the following wiki page: https://trac.sdss.org/wiki/MANGA/Data/DataProductsProposals/Portsmouth_VAC.
vacs.title: MaNGA Firefly Stellar Populations
vacs.abstract: The MaNGA Firefly Stellar Populations VAC is based on the MaNGA DAP output and extends through stellar population model fitting. It complements the DAP by providing higher-order and model-based data products. The data products are centred on the full spectral fitting analysis carried out at the Portsmouth supercomputer. The data included in the VAC is used in several scientific analyses (SDSS-IV projects 100, 309 and others in future). More information can be found in the MaNGA product proposal posted on the following wiki page: https://trac.sdss.org/wiki/MANGA/Data/DataProductsProposals/Portsmouth_VAC.
vacs.authors: Daniel Thomas, Daniel Goddard, Claudia Maraston, Taniya Parikh, Jianhui Lian, Johan Comparat, Sofia Meneses-Goytia, Violeta Perez-Gonzalez, Kyle Westfall

vacs.description: We processed all public SDSS galaxy spectra using the recent full-spectral-fitting pipeline, FIREFLY, to propose new measurements of their stellar population properties such as stellar age, metallicity and mass.
vacs.title: Firefly Stellar Population Models of SDSS and eBOSS galaxy spectra
vacs.abstract: We processed all public SDSS galaxy spectra using the recent full-spectral-fitting pipeline, FIREFLY, to propose new measurements of their stellar population properties such as stellar age, metallicity and mass.
vacs.authors: Johan Comparat, Claudia Maraston, Violeta Perez-Gonzalez

vacs.description: We provide the catalogue of X-ray detected galaxy clusters spectroscopically confirmed using DR14 SPIDERS spectroscopic data. Galaxy clusters were identified through the emission of their hot baryonic component as X-ray extended sources in ROSAT and XMM-Newton observations. The optical counterparts were found by optimally searching photometric data for the existence of a red-sequence formed by their member galaxies. Spectroscopic redshifts obtained by SPIDERS (DR14) provide confirmation of the clustered nature of these objects and their redshift (up to z~0.6). We assigned cluster membership combining an algorithm and multiple independent visual validations of individual objects. The gas properties derived from X-ray observations (luminosity, R500, etc.) are derived using precise cluster redshifts and they provide an estimate of their total mass (median M200c ~ 5.1014 Msun). We compute galaxy cluster dynamical mass proxies using methods adapted to the low number of spectroscopic members per system (median ~13). The catalogues will include the membership of red-sequence galaxies.
vacs.title: SPIDERS x-ray galaxy cluster catalogue for DR14
vacs.abstract: We provide the catalogue of X-ray detected galaxy clusters spectroscopically confirmed using DR14 SPIDERS spectroscopic data. Galaxy clusters were identified through the emission of their hot baryonic component as X-ray extended sources in ROSAT and XMM-Newton observations. The optical counterparts were found by optimally searching photometric data for the existence of a red-sequence formed by their member galaxies. Spectroscopic redshifts obtained by SPIDERS (DR14) provide confirmation of the clustered nature of these objects and their redshift (up to z~0.6). We assigned cluster membership combining an algorithm and multiple independent visual validations of individual objects. The gas properties derived from X-ray observations (luminosity, R500, etc.) are derived using precise cluster redshifts and they provide an estimate of their total mass (median M200c ~ 5.1014 Msun). We compute galaxy cluster dynamical mass proxies using methods adapted to the low number of spectroscopic members per system (median ~13). The catalogues will include the membership of red-sequence galaxies.
vacs.authors: Nicolas Clerc, Raffaella Capasso, Ghazaleh Erfanianfar, Alexis Finoguenov, Kate Furnell, Charles C. Kirpatrick IV, Nelson Padilla, Alex Saro, the SPIDERS team

vacs.description: We present multi-wavelegth characterization of a highly complete sample of ROSAT All-Sky Survey (2RXS) point-like sources over the area covered by the SEQUELS and eBOSS DR14 surveys. We provide information about X-ray properteis of the sources, as well as of their counterparts at longer wavelength (Optical, IR, Radio) identified first in the All-WISE IR catalog via a Bayesian cross-matching algorithm. We complement this with dedicated visual inspection of the SDSS spectra, providing accurate redshift estimates (with objective confidence levels) and source classification, beyond the standard eBOSS pipeline results.
vacs.title: Multiwavelength properties of RASS AGN
vacs.abstract: We present multi-wavelegth characterization of a highly complete sample of ROSAT All-Sky Survey (2RXS) point-like sources over the area covered by the SEQUELS and eBOSS DR14 surveys. We provide information about X-ray properteis of the sources, as well as of their counterparts at longer wavelength (Optical, IR, Radio) identified first in the All-WISE IR catalog via a Bayesian cross-matching algorithm. We complement this with dedicated visual inspection of the SDSS spectra, providing accurate redshift estimates (with objective confidence levels) and source classification, beyond the standard eBOSS pipeline results.
vacs.authors: Andrea Merloni, Antonis Georgakakis, Agnese Del Moro, Mara Salvato, Tom Dwelly, Kirpal Nandra, Johan Comparat, Damien Coffey

vacs.description: We present multi-wavelegth characterization of a highly complete sample of XMM-Slew Survey point-like sources over the area covered by the SEQUELS and eBOSS DR14 surveys. We provide information about X-ray properties of the sources, as well as of their counterparts at longer wavelength (Optical, IR, Radio) identified first in the All-WISE IR catalog via a Bayesian cross-matching algorithm. We complement this with dedicated visual inspection of the SDSS spectra, providing accurate redshift estimates (with objective confidence levels) and source classification, beyond the standard eBOSS pipeline results.
vacs.title: Multi-wavelength properties of XMM-Slew Survey AGN
vacs.abstract: We present multi-wavelegth characterization of a highly complete sample of XMM-Slew Survey point-like sources over the area covered by the SEQUELS and eBOSS DR14 surveys. We provide information about X-ray properties of the sources, as well as of their counterparts at longer wavelength (Optical, IR, Radio) identified first in the All-WISE IR catalog via a Bayesian cross-matching algorithm. We complement this with dedicated visual inspection of the SDSS spectra, providing accurate redshift estimates (with objective confidence levels) and source classification, beyond the standard eBOSS pipeline results.
vacs.authors: Andrea Merloni, Antonis Georgakakis, Agnese Del Moro, Mara Salvato, Tom Dwelly, Kirpal Nandra, Johan Comparat, Damien Coffey
